# Building JS Apps with API Data
---

Hello, [Wrold](https://medium.com/@the_taqquikarim/console-log-hello-wrold-3e3abeb44396#.vk701xxec)! Welcome to Javascript APIs.

### Objective
---
Our main today is to learn how we can leverage 3rd party APIs to enrich our webpages with dynamic data.

We will cover **public APIs** only, since those don't require anything more than some js code to configure. This means we will **not** talk about the twitter or facebook APIs which require a user authentication component to work correctly.

### Game Plan
---

#### [Warm-up: Simple GET requests](#warm-up)
The assumption is you've probably worked with API data before. Even if you have not, with jQuery, it's literally just 4 or 5 lines of code to get started.

#### [Wrangling Asynchronousness: Dealing with multiple requests](#wrangling-asynchronousness)
How do we force asynchronous requests to execute in order?

#### [Exploring RESTful APIs: What is REST?](#exploring-restful-apis)
We have a good handle on GET requests, but what about all the other types? Specifically POST, PUT, DELETE?

#### [Using Promises: Better handling asynchronous requests](#using-promises)
What are promises and how can we use them to make it easier for us to draw data together from multiple sources?

warm-up.content:
# Warm-up: Simple GET requests
---

Let's take a moment to define the term `API` and how we can use them to retrieve data from remote resources.

## Using APIs
---
Simply put, working with APIs require three distinct steps.

### Requesting Data
Requesting data involves delving into API documentation to understand which API endpoints to direct your requests towards.

Then, you must actually make the GET request.


### Retrieving Data
Data retrieval involves taking the server response from your GET requests.

Typically, server responses will send back data in JSON format. It is up to the API consumer (you) to determine how to extract that data for usage in your app.

Also, don't forget to handle errors!

### Displaying Data
This final piece involves updating the UI of your application with the data you extracted from the server response.

Generally, the techniques you may know from jQuery for injecting data won't do here. We will use some form of templating system to achieve our data displaying needs.

## Project Work
---

#### Project 1 (we do)
We will build a simple Giphy Search Engine. User will input a search query which will lead to results rendered as gifs.

**Requesting data**

Here is the [Giphy API](https://api.giphy.com/) documentation.

We will also implement our own `$.get` request to understand the guts of how AJAX is handled in javascript.

```js
const $ = {
    get() {
        /* ...implement GET... */
    }
};
```

**Retrieving Data**

Ideally, we want to take the JSON response and convert it into an array or some other type of data structure that makes it easy for us to access the giph info (specifically in this case, the giph URL).

**Displaying Data**

We will use es6 string interpolation to handle our "templating". This is the most lightweight and easiest option.


#### Follow up (you do)
Build in an **I'm feeling lucky** feature. (In other words, user should be able to perform a search query and get back the top result **only**).

Use the methods we've written in **Project 1** as much as possible to complete this problem.
